div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, NINTH CIRCUITM DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In re Frank E. Corbin (Writ of habeas corpus--Return of respondent.)
To the Honorable Judge of the said Court.

The respondent, Colonel Joseph F, Huston, 19th Infantry, upon whom hasbeen served a writ of habeas corpus for the pro- duction of Frank E. Corbin, respectfully makes return and states that as Commanding Officer of the Military Port of Van- couver Barracks, Washington, he holds the said Frank E. Corbin by authority of the United States under the following circum- stances:

That on the 30th day of November, 1903, at Seattle Wash- ington, the said Frank E. Corbin, being then a minor, did fraud- ulently enlist in the military service of the United States for the term of three years by falsely representing that he was twenty-one years and four months old, and that the said Frank E. Corbin has since the said fraudulent enlistment received pay and allowance thereunder.

That the said Frank E. Corbin has been placed in confine- ment, charged with said offense, and formal charge against him therefor have been preferred, a copy of which is hereto annexed, and that he will be brought to trial thereon as soon as practic- able before a general court-martial convened by Special Orders, No. 6, dated Headquarters Department of Columbia, Vancouver Barracks, Washington, January 11th, 1904, a copy of which is hereto annexed.

In obedience, however, to the said writ of HABEAS CORPUS, the respondent herewith produces before the Court the body of the said Frank E. Corbin, respectfully refers to the decisions cited in the annexed brief, and for the reasons set forth in this return prays this honorable Court to dismiss the said writ.
J. F. Huson Colonel, 19th U. S. Infantry.
Dated, Vancouver Barracks, Washington January 16, 1904
Jesse Attys U. S. Atty
Edward E. Cushman Asst. US Atty W. A. Bethel Attorney for respondent.
CHARGES AND SPECIFICATION PREFERRED AGAINST Private Frank E. Corbin, Company "D", 19th Infantry.
CHARGE: Fradualent enlistment in violatoin of the 62nd Article of War.

Specification; In that Private Frank E. Corbin, Company "D", 19th Infantry, did at Seattle, Washington, on the 30th day of November 1903, he being a minor, fraudulently enlist as a soldier in the service of the United States by falsely representing himself to befoore over 21 years, to wit, 21 years and 4 months of age, and that he has since said fraudulent enlistment received pay and allowances thereunder.
Ths at Seattle, Washingotn, and Vancouver Barracks, Washington, on and after about November 30th 1903.
GSW Herberts Cap't and Adj't 19th Infantry Officer Preferring Charges.
WITNESSES: Sergeant Mohr, Recruiting Station, Seattle, Wash. Corbin, (Father of accused)
PREVIOUS CONVICTIONS: one (1)
(duplicant)
THE UNITED STATES VERSUS FRANK E. CORBIN, Private Company "D" 19th Infantry.
Violation of the 62nd A. W. (Fraudulent Enlistment) The Specification.
1st Indorsement.
Vancouver Barracks, Washington, January 16, 1904.
Respectfully forwarded to the Adjutant General, Depart- ment of the Columbia, recommend- ing trial by general court mar- tial.
I have investigated this case and believe the charges can be sustained.
Statements of service and record of previous convictions inclosed.
J. F. Huston Colonel 19th Infantry, Commanding. (2 Incl's.) (application)
2nd Indorsement. HEADQRS. DEPT, OF THE COLUMBIA, VANCOUVER BARRACKS, WASH., JAN, 16, 1904. To the Judge Advocate, D. C.
3rd Endorsement HEADQUARTERS DEPT OF THE COLUMBIA. JUDGE ADVOCATE'S OFFICE, VANCOUVER BARRACKS WASH. Jany 16 1904 Respectfully returned recommended for trial by General Court- Martial
W. A. Bethel
Major and Judge advocate, U. S. Army, Judge Advocate.
4th Indorsement HEADQUARTERS DEPT OF THE COLUMBIA VANCOUVER BARRACKS, WASH., JAN, 16, 1904.

Respectfully referred to 2nd Lt. R. E. Taylor, 19th Infantry, judge advocate of the general court-martial convened by paragraph 1 Special Orders No. 6 current series, from these head- quarters, for trial.
By command of Brigadjer General FUNSTON
R. K. Evans
Major, Adjutant General

I certify that the within charges together with the endorsements hereon are true copies of papers in the case of the United States vs. Frank C. Corbin, which have been refered from this of- fice to a general court-mar- tial for trial.
R. K. Evans Major, Adjutant General, Department of the Colum- bia.
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF THE COLUMBIA, VANCOUVER BARRACKS, WASH., JANUARY 11, 1904.
SPECIAL ORDERS
NO. 6

1.- A general court-martial is appointed to meet at Vancouver Barracks, Wash., at 10 o'clock, a. m. on Friday, January 15, 1904, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for thee trial of such persons as may be properly brought before it.
Detail for the Court.
Major James B. Goe, 19th Infantry
Captain Truman O. Murphy, 19th Infantry
Captain Harry L. Hawthorne, Artillery Corps.
Captain Berkeley Enochs, 19th Infantry.
1st Liuetenant G. Arthur Hadsell, 19th Infantry.
1st Lieutenant Arthur W. Morse, Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army.
1st Lieutenant Harry E. Mitchell, Artillery Corps.
1st Lieutenant William P. Screws, Batallion Adjutant 19th Infantry.
2d Lieutenant Charles M. Allen, Artillery Corps.
2d Lieutenant Walter K. Wilson, Artillery Corps.
2d Lieutenant James B. Nalle, 19th Infantry.
2d Lieutenant Reuben C. Taylor, 19th Infantry, judge advocate.
A greater number of officer cannot be assembled without man- ifest injury to the service.
By command of Brigader General FUNSTON:
R. K. Evans Major, Adjutant General
Official: B. J. MITCHELL, 1st Lieut. 12th Infantry, Aid-de-Camp.
IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, NINTH CIRCUIT, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In re Frank E. Corbin.
B R I E F O F R E S P O N D E N T .

A CONTRACT OF ENLISTMENT IS NOT VOIDABLE BY PARENTS OR GUARD- IANS IF THE SOLDIER IS HELD PURSUANT TO A SENTENCE OF A COURT- MARTIAL OR ANY STEP HAS BEEN TAKEN WITH A VIEW TO BRINGING HIM BEFORE SUCH COURT.

In re Kaufman, 41 Federal Reporter, 876; In re Dohrendorf, et al., 40 Federal Reporter, 148; In re Cosenow, 37 Federal Re- porter, 668; In re Dowd, 90 Federal Reporter, 718; Ex parte Anderson, 16 Iowa.

In the Kaufman case, the father sought the discharge of his son, who was held by the military authorities and had been ordered before a military court for trial as a deserter. Quot- ing from the syllabus:

A minor who enlists in the United States Army upon hs rep= resentation that he is of age, and receives pay and clothing and afterwards deserts and is arrested as a deserter, and at the time of his petition is held by the United States awaiting trial by a court-martial for the crime of desertion, will not be released under a writ of HABEAS CORPUS upon the ground that being a minor his enlistment was unlawful contrary to the Revised Statutes of the United States.

In the Cosenow case the minor swore that he was twenty-one years and seven months old at the time of enlistment. He deserted, and at the time of the filing of the petition was held in custody awaiting the action of the reviewing authority on the proceedigs of the court-martial. His father sought the discharge of his son on the ground of infancy at the time of enlistment. The court refused to discharge him, holding that "an enlistment contrary to law is not void, but voidable;" that the court-mar- tial had jurisdiction of the offense, and the soldier "must be remanded to await the result of his trial."
The Dowd case arose on the application of the mother for the release of her son, who was held under sentence of a summary of court. The court held, quoting from the syllabus:

The enlistment of a minor in the Army without the consent of his parents or guardian, required by Revised Statutes, section 1117, is not void, but voidable only, and while he remains in the service under such enlistment the mino is amendable to the Ar- ticles of War, and can not be remanded to the custody of his par- ents by a civil court on a writ of HABEAS CORPUS while undergong a sentence imposed on him by a court-martial for a violation of such articles.

In the Anderson cas,e the father procured a writ of HABEAS CORPUS for the purpose of obtaining the discharge of his minor son from the military custody in which he was held. It was ad- mitted by the pleadings that the relator's son was a minor when he enlisted and that he enlisted without his parents consent.
The Judge's decision was as follows:

I therefore hold that the return of the respondent in this case, that he holds the prisoner for the crime of desertion, and that heis now awaiting his trial before a court-martial is suf- ficient, and that he must abide by the decision of the latter court, before the question of the validity of his enlistment can be determined by the civil courts on HABEAS CORPUS.

Section 3 of an act of Congress amending the Articles of War and for others purposes, approved July 27, 1892, provides: "That fraudulent enlistment, and the receipt of anypay or allow- ance thereunder, is hereby declared a military offense and made punishiable by court-martial under the Sixty-second Article of War."

In Circular No. 13 of the War Department for 1892, the Acting Secretary of War decided that cases of fraudulent enlistment should be tried before a general court-martial. That circular declared fraudulent enlistment to be "an enlistment procured by means of a willful misrepresentation in regard to a qualifica- tion or disqualification for enlistment, or by an intentional concealment of a disqualification which has had the effect of causing the enlistment of a man not qualified to be a soldier, and who but for such false representation or concealment would have been rejected.

Section 1117, Revised Statutes, provides that: "No person under the age of twenty-one years shall be enlisted or mustered into the military service of the United States without the written consent of his parents or guardian; PROVIDED, That such minor has such parens or guardians entitled to his custody and control."

A minor who obtains his enlistment into the military ser- vice of the United States by falsely representing that he is twenty-one years old is guilty of fraudulent enlistment and is amendable to trial by a military court-martial which has exclus- ive jurisdiction in such case.

Should a civil court discharge from the Army a minor who is under charges and awaiting trial by court-martial for desertion, fradulent enlistment, or any other offense prescribed by the Ar- ticles of War or other acts of Congress, it would disregard the Constitutional power of Congress "To make rules for the Govern- ment and Regulation of the land and naval forces."

Under the custom of the service the parents or guardian of a minor who enlists without their consent can obtain his discharge upon application to the Secretary of War, prior to the commis- sion of a military offense. Their right under section 1117, Revised Statutes are thus sufficiently protected; but when the minor has committed a military offense the interests of the pub- lic in the administration of justice are paramount to the right sequence of his offense before the right to his dischagr be passed upon. (Digest Opin. J. A. G., SS 1258 and 1204, and notes.)

The soldier should not be allowed to escape punishment for his offense, even though his parents assert their right to his ser- vices. A minor in civil life is liable to punishment for a crime or misdemeanor, even though his confinement nay interfere with the rights of his parents.
Jesse A Nye U.S. Atty
Edward E. Cushman
W. A. Bethel Attorney for respondent.
In The U. S. Circuit Courtm District of Washington
Northern Division
In re Frank E. Corbin -habeas Corpus
Return of Respondent
FILED IN THE U. S. Cicruit Court.
DIST. OF WASHINGTON.
A. REEVES AYRES, Clerk.
HM Matthew Deputy
